question_details.title: Will evidence of alien technology be recovered near the IM1 crash site before 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2023-07-21 19:16:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/17917). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

In his book [*Extraterrestrial*](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/astronomer-avi-loeb-says-aliens-have-visited-and-hes-not-kidding1/), Harvard astrophysicist [Avi Loeb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avi_Loeb) suggests that a 2017 interstellar object known as ['Oumuamua](https://solarsystem.nasa.gov/asteroids-comets-and-meteors/comets/oumuamua/in-depth/) is ["interstellar technology built by aliens"](https://www.independent.co.uk/space/avi-loeb-harvard-university-ufos-b2039269.html).

Inspired by partially by ‘Oumuamua, Loeb founded [The Galileo Project](https://projects.iq.harvard.edu/galileo/) in 2021 to "[systematically search for extraterrestrial intelligence or extraterrestrial technology on and near Earth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Galileo_Project)." Galileo planned and [secured funding for](https://avi-loeb.medium.com/message-in-an-interstellar-bottle-c393ea526e9f) an [expedition](https://avi-loeb.medium.com/summary-of-the-successful-interstellar-expedition-61ff4467070d) to recover portions of an object known as [CNEOS 2014-01-08](https://www.space.com/2014-meteor-first-interstellar-visitor-oumuamua), commonly called [Interstellar Meteor 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNEOS_2014-01-08) (IM1), which crashed of the coast of Papua New Guinea on January 8th, 2014. 

IM1 became a target of interest for The Gallileo Project when Loeb and a student, [Amir Siraj](https://scholar.harvard.edu/siraj/home), submitted a [preprint](https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.07224) arguing—citing a US Department of Defense [memo](https://lweb.cfa.harvard.edu/~loeb/DoD.pdf)—that the object originated outside the solar system.

> we identify the ∼0.45m meteor detected at 2014-01-08 17:05:34 UTC as originating from an unbound hyperbolic orbit with 99.999\% confidence. The U.S. Department of Defense has since verified that "the velocity estimate reported to NASA is sufficiently accurate to indicate an interstellar trajectory."

If Loeb and Siraj are correct, then IM1 is the first [interstellar object](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstellar_object) scientifically known to impact the earth. Other scientists have [disputed](https://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/acm2023/pdf/2226.pdf) their conclusions.


Based on IM1's observed toughness, Loeb believes that not only may the object be interstellar, but that it could be [alien technology](https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20230626-the-underwater-search-for-an-alien-object). To [quote Loeb](https://avi-loeb.medium.com/message-in-an-interstellar-bottle-c393ea526e9f):

> There are two general possibilities. Either IM1 is of new natural origin, or it is artificial, produced by an extraterrestrial technological civilization. Regarding the first possibility, X-ray imaging of the Vela supernova remnant [revealed](https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1995Natur.373..590S/abstract) bow shocks from bullets flying out of the explosion site, a discovery [I attempted to explain](https://arxiv.org/pdf/astro-ph/9405071.pdf) three decades ago. It is possible that IM1 was a small bullet tougher than conventional iron meteorites, shot out of an exploding star. But it is also possible that it was a spacecraft, a billion-year old equivalent of our [interstellar probes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstellar_probe). Just [imagine](https://avi-loeb.medium.com/the-new-horizons-meteor-a62a3bb177b7) a spacecraft like Voyager 1 & 2, Pioneer 10 & 11 or New Horizons, crashing onto a habitable exo-planet and burning up in its atmosphere. The exo-scientists on this exo-planet would regard the resulting exo-meteor as space trash. However, if they are curious enough to examine the composition of its fragments, they would realize that it was artificial in origin.

Using a [massive magnetic sled](https://www.livescience.com/interstellar-asteroid-fishing-expedition) to scrape the seabed, Loeb's expedition found [50 spherules](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/avi-loeb-interstellar-object-aliens-b2369534.html) which Loeb believes are portions of IM1. Loeb says these spherules are now being [analyzed](https://avi-loeb.medium.com/starting-the-analysis-of-spherules-from-the-interstellar-expedition-2bc608d2d7ce) by "three laboratories in UC Berkeley, Harvard and the Bruker Corporation in Germany." Loeb is providing regular updates on his [blog](https://avi-loeb.medium.com/starting-the-analysis-of-spherules-from-the-interstellar-expedition-2bc608d2d7ce).

> The fundamental question we will address is whether the elements and radioactive isotopes in the spherules have different abundances than solar system materials. If so, we would also check for any anomalies that might indicate a technological origin. For example, the melted material of semiconductors would include rare elements at a much higher abundance than found in nature.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":17917,"question_id":17917}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question resolves **Yes** if a systematic review of material gathered from the IM1 crash site off the coast of Papua New Guinea concludes all of the following:

- With 95% confidence, the material did not originate on Earth
- With 95% confidence, the material reflects a technological origin—that is, there is no known natural process that could create material of this composition.

Such a systematic review should be peer-reviewed and should incorporate analyses of recovered material from at least 3 independent labs. It must be published before January 1, 2026.

Here are the relevant news articles:

**Could 3I/ATLAS Be Artificial? Harvard Expert Lists 7 'Anomalies' That Challenge Its Comet Classification**
Astrophysicist Avi Loeb from Harvard University has identified seven unusual behaviors and characteristics in the interstellar object 3I/ATLAS that, in his view, challenge its classification as a natural comet. The object, the third interstellar visitor detected in our Solar System, continues to spark scientific debate. Loeb, a prominent and controversial figure in modern astronomy and leader of the Galileo Project for the search of extraterrestrial technology, argues that the scientific community must seriously consider these anomalies and not dismiss the possibility of an artificial or technological origin. He urges scientists to move beyond 'dogmatic' assumptions of a purely natural origin and to fully explain all observed discrepancies before ruling out the most remote possibility. NASA and other observatories are continuing to analyze data to better understand this enigmatic object, which will reach its closest point to the Sun in October 2025.
Original language: es
Publish date: October 14, 2025 01:49 PM
Source:[FayerWayer](https://www.fayerwayer.com/espacio/2025/10/14/origen-no-natural-experto-de-harvard-lista-7-anomalias-que-desvinculan-a-3iatlas-de-ser-solo-un-cometa/)

**Alien 'Trojan Horse' Approaching Earth: What We Know About 3I/ATLAS**
The interstellar object 3I/ATLAS, currently traversing the Solar System, is the subject of intense scientific debate set to culminate on October 29, 2025, when it will approach the Sun and reveal its true nature—whether it is a natural comet, as claimed by NASA, or potentially an extraordinary technological artifact. Harvard University professor Avi Loeb proposes that 3I/ATLAS could be an alien 'Trojan horse,' disguised as a natural body, with its solar approach serving as a critical test of this hypothesis. If the object is natural, it is expected to disintegrate under thermal stress, as comets typically do. However, Loeb estimates a 30-40% chance that it is not fully natural and might instead behave like a technological 'mother ship,' deploying a fleet of mini-probes to explore the Solar System. Major space assets, including ESA's Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer (Juice) and ground-based telescopes in November and December, will observe the event. So far, ESA's Mars orbiters have detected no confirmed fragments, and NASA images show a cylindrical shape and a distinctive green glow. Loeb dismissed viral claims of mysterious objects near 3I/ATLAS as misidentified stars or Mars satellites. The scientific community awaits the October 2025 event, which could either confirm a natural origin or provide the first compelling evidence of extraterrestrial technology.
Original language: uk
Publish date: October 14, 2025 07:20 AM
Source:[ТСН.ua](https://tsn.ua/nauka_it/do-zemli-letyt-troianskyy-kin-prybultsiv-shcho-vidomo-2933831.html)

**Harvard Professor Urges UN to Act: 'Aliens Might Invade Us'**
Harvard University's astrophysics professor Avi Loeb warned the United Nations to take urgent precautions, claiming that the interstellar object 3I/ATLAS, discovered on July 1, 2025, could potentially harbor extraterrestrial life and that humanity lacks the capability to defend itself against a possible alien invasion. Loeb argues that mysterious light flares detected on the front of 3I/ATLAS may be reflections of unknown alien technology and suggests the object could deploy sensors on Earth, which might be observed as Unidentified Aerial Phenomena (UAP). He emphasizes that alien technology may remain incomprehensible to humans. However, NASA disputes this view, stating that 3I/ATLAS will reach its closest point to Earth on October 30, 2025, at a distance of 209 million kilometers—sufficiently safe to pose no threat or collision risk.

**Harvard Expert Predicts 3I/ATLAS Will Reveal Itself as an 'Alien Spaceship' and Deploy 'Mini Probes'**
The interstellar object 3I/ATLAS, discovered by the ATLAS telescope in Chile, has sparked debate and speculation since its detection as it travels toward the Sun. While officially classified as a comet, Harvard University expert Avi Loeb, director of the Galileo Project, argues it is not a natural comet but a functional extraterrestrial spacecraft with non-human technology. Loeb claims the object is 'exceptionally large' for a typical icy comet and exhibits unusual speed, trajectory, and color, suggesting artificial origin. He posits that its path avoids close Earth approach during lunar alignment in late October to evade human monitoring. On October 29, 2025, as the object nears the Sun, it may either disintegrate like a comet or reveal itself as a technological craft. Loeb estimates a 30% to 40% chance the object is not entirely natural, possibly acting as a 'Trojan horse'—a technological probe disguised as a comet. If not destroyed by solar heat, the object could deploy a fleet of 'mini probes' to study multiple celestial bodies simultaneously, similar to a technological mothership. The European Space Agency's Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer (Juice) will monitor the object in November and December 2025, and ground-based observatories may verify the release of mini probes, supporting Loeb’s hypothesis. According to Loeb, solar radiation heats a comet’s icy core, causing volatile ices like carbon dioxide and water to sublimate into gas, potentially fracturing the comet under thermal stress.
Original language: es

Source:[ViveUSA.mx](https://www.viveusa.mx/destinos/experto-de-harvard-predice-que-el-3iatlas-se-revelara-como-una-nave-extraterrestre-y-liberara-mini-sondas/)

**SETI Scientist Tries To Debunk Harvard Astrophysicist's Claims Comet May Be An Alien Spacecraft**
Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS has sparked debate over whether it could be an alien spacecraft, primarily due to claims by Avi Loeb, former chairman of Harvard's Department of Astronomy and head of the Galileo Project. Loeb, who previously suggested that 1I/'Oumuamua might be extraterrestrial, stated in July 2025 that 3I/ATLAS may be traveling to avoid Earth-based observation and noted seven anomalies in its behavior, assigning a 30–40% likelihood that it has a non-natural origin, including the possibility of a 'Trojan Horse' scenario. In response, Eahsanul Haque, a SETI Institute scientist and senior lecturer at Universiti Teknologi Petronas, published a paper arguing that the comet’s hyperbolic trajectory (eccentricity ~6.1), high speed (~58 km/s), and low probability of close encounters with planets (~0.005%) are consistent with gravitational ejection from another star system, similar to 1I/'Oumuamua and 2I/Borisov. Tom Statler, NASA’s lead scientist for solar system small bodies, emphasized that 3I/ATLAS 'looks like a comet. It does comet things' and behaves like known comets, calling the evidence 'overwhelmingly pointing to this object being a natural body.' Despite this, Loeb warned that if his hypothesis were correct, the consequences could be 'dire for humanity' and might necessitate defensive measures, though they 'might prove futile.'

The Galileo Project. While government agencies such as NASA and the Pentagon are increasingly opening up space for analysis of unidentified phenomena, one of the most daring and controversial attempts comes from the academic community, but outside institutional funding. Astro physicist Avi Loeb from Harvard University founded the Galileo Project, a privately funded scientific program that deals with the search for traces of extraterrestrial technology near Earth, including the atmosphere, orbit, and ocean floor. The project uses high-resolution optics, spectroscopy, radar, magnetic detectors, and advanced data processing algorithms in real-time. Systems have already been set up at several locations in the US, and the goal is to create a global network for continuous monitoring of anomalous objects that do not belong to known civil, military, or natural classes. summary:
All forecasting experts converge on an extremely low probability that evidence of alien technology will be recovered near the IM1 crash site before 2026, as defined by the resolution criteria. Every domain—spanning forensic materials analysis, aerospace engineering, astrophysics, planetary science, and philosophy of science—emphasizes the extraordinary stringency of the required standard: at least three independent, peer-reviewed laboratory analyses published before January 1, 2026, concluding with >95% confidence both non-terrestrial and technological (not naturally possible) origin for any recovered material. 

Despite high-profile claims by Avi Loeb and the Galileo Project and some reported compositional anomalies (e.g., beryllium, lanthanum, uranium enrichment in spherules), all credible analyses indicate that such claims either face plausible natural explanations (supernova products, contamination, rare meteoritic phenomena) or have not been validated or broadly accepted in the scientific literature. Experts note that the peer review process is especially slow and conservative for paradigm-shifting discoveries, and that, as of October 2025, no multi-laboratory, peer-reviewed systematic review has been published or even been publicly hinted as forthcoming.

Historical base rates for similar extraordinary claims (alien technology, technosignatures, non-terrestrial artifacts) are zero, and all prior anomalies have ultimately been attributed to natural causes or dismissed due to insufficient evidence. While there is acknowledgment that the Galileo Project is better positioned than most to attempt such a discovery, and that publicity could modestly increase the chance of rapid review or breakthrough, this is overwhelmingly outweighed by the timelines involved, the compound evidence standard, and strongly entrenched scientific skepticism.

The experts agree that scenarios for a 'No' outcome are straightforward: analyses continue, perhaps with intriguing or ambiguous results, but natural explanations or uncertainty prevail, and no peer-reviewed publication achieves the required level of certainty before the deadline. 'Yes' scenarios, in contrast, would require unprecedented scientific consensus and overwhelmingly clear multi-lab evidence on an impossibly short timeline—something universally judged highly unlikely. Final probability estimates cluster at 0–2%, with all experts pointing to the lack of evidence, procedural and epistemic barriers, and negative historical precedent as overwhelming factors.
